## In-text Citations {.smaller}

![](images/APA_style.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="120" height="80"}

According to the American Psychology association (APA), in-text citations must be used when you cite someone's "...ideas, theories, or research..."(APA publication manual, 2019, p. 281). For example:

:::{.fragment}

> Employees experience negative outcomes such as stress and disengagement when their organizational leaders lack emotional and social skills **(Nowack & Zak, 2020)**. 

:::

:::{.fragment}

As you can see, the general form of an In-text citation is the *(author~(s)~ name~(s)~, publication year)*. When the source has *3 or more authors*, you should just cite the first author followed by *et. al*:

> Children with autism spectrum disorder are often very selective about what food they will eat and experience difficulties during mealtimes (Burrell **et al.**, 2019).

:::

:::{.fragment}

Finally, you can also cite someone by using them as the sentence subject:

> **Burrell et al. (2019)** discussed how children with autism spectrum disorder are often very selective about what food they will eat and experience difficulties during mealtimes.

:::


## Multiple In-text citations and Direct </br> quotes {.smaller}

![](images/APA_style.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="120" height="80"}

:::{.fragment}
Sometimes, you need to cite multiple sources to back up one of your statements. If so, remember that the sources should be *ordered alphabetically* and separated by a "*;*":

> Several studies have replicated these results (**B**rown, 2009**;** **P**orter, 2004**;** **S**mith, 2015, 2017).
:::

</br> 

:::{.fragment}

**Direct quotes** from other sources function very similar to in-text citations, but have a few differences; when the quote is *under 40 words*, the only addition necessary is enclosing the sentence within *quotations* and including the *page number*:

> According to a recent paper, ‚Äúquotes can be useful in academic writing‚Äù (Singh et al., 2019**, p. 25**).

:::

:::{.fragment}
When the quote is *over 40 words*, you need to enclose the sentence within a [block-quote](https://www.scribbr.com/working-with-sources/block-quote/){target="_blank"}. 

However, I don't think that this case should come up in your lab reports.
:::

## References: Journal Article {.smaller}

![](images/APA_style.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="120" height="80"}

At its end, every APA style manuscript should have a "references" section including the full references of all the sources cited in the main text. <u> The format of the reference changes depending on the source </u>(e.g., journal article, [book chapter](https://guides.library.uq.edu.au/referencing/apa7/book-chapter){target="_blank}, poster presentation, etc..). 

By far, the most common type of sources are *journal articles*. The general format for journal article references is:

[Author, A. A., Author, B. B., & Author, C. C.]{.fragment fragment-index="1" style="color: red;"}[(Year of publication).]{.fragment fragment-index="2" style="color: blue;"}[Title of article.]{.fragment fragment-index="3" style="color: orange;"}[*Title of Journal*,]{.fragment fragment-index="4" style="color: magenta;"}[*volume number*]{.fragment fragment-index="5" style="color: grey;"}[(issue number),]{.fragment fragment-index="6" style="color: HotPink;"} [pages.]{.fragment fragment-index="7" style="color: purple;"}

:::{.fragment fragment-index="1"}
> [Azen, R., & Budescu, D. V.]{.fragment fragment-index="1" style="color: red;"} [(2006).]{.fragment fragment-index="2" style="color: blue;"} [Comparing predictors in multivariate regression models: An extension of dominance analysis.]{.fragment fragment-index="3" style="color: orange;"} [*Journal of Educational and Behavioral Statistics*,]{.fragment fragment-index="4" style="color: magenta;"} [*31*]{.fragment fragment-index="5" style="color: grey;"}[(2),]{.fragment fragment-index="6" style="color: HotPink;"} [157‚Äì180.]{.fragment fragment-index="7" style="color: purple;"}
:::

<br /> <br />

:::{.fragment fragment-index="8"}
<p style="text-align: center;"> **There are many types of sources, so always make sure you are using the correct reference format given the source.** </p>
:::


## Numbers

![](images/APA_style.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="120" height="80"}

:::{.fragment}
**1.** Always spell out numbers when the number in question is not a statistic, below 10 OR is at the beginning of a line (e.g., "two" instead of "2"). Always use numerals for 10 or above.
:::

<br/> 

:::{.fragment}
**2.** Round all numbers to **2 decimal places**. However, always round **p-values** to **3 decimal place**. 
:::

<br/>

:::{.fragment}
**3.** Use a leading 0 only for numbers that can be larger than 1. For example, correlations and *p*-values can only range between -1/1 and 0/1 respectively, and do not need a leading 0 (e.g., "*r* = .57" instead of "*r* = 0.57") 
:::

## Abbreviations

![](images/APA_style.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="120" height="80"}

Abbreviations are usually employed for words that are repeated multiple times throughout a manuscript (e.g., "APA" in these slides). 

</br>

:::{.fragment}
The only rule to remember is to introduce the abbreviation the *1~st~ time the full word is presented*, and then *only* use the abbreviation for the rest of the paper:

> **Response time (RT)** was used as a measure of reaction speed. However, one has to keep in mind that pure **RT** may not fully capture the construct under investigation.
:::


:::{.fragment}
Finally, Remember that using too many abbreviations may cause confusion. 
:::

![](images/APA_style.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="120" height="80"}

There are many APA style resources. Some notable ones are...

:::{.fragment}
- [APA style Handouts and guides](https://apastyle.apa.org/instructional-aids/handouts-guides#mastering){preview-link="true"}: Checklists and examples of common APA style practices.
:::

:::{.fragment}
- [Purdue OWL](https://owl.purdue.edu/owl/research_and_citation/apa_style/apa_formatting_and_style_guide/index.html){preview-link="true"}: Comprehensive and neatly packaged APA style guides. 
:::

:::{.fragment}
- [APA Publicartion Manual](https://apastyle.apa.org/products/publication-manual-7th-edition){preview-link="true"}: Goes without saying, but contains everything you need to know about APA. 
:::

- [Google](https://www.google.com){target="_blank"}: I know this sounds obvious, but just about all the answers you need can be found by knowing what to look for in Google (maybe even PDFs of certain publication manuals? ü§´).
